I'm a little confused by how to say a rhythm. So apparently you can count 16th notes in a 4/4 by saying "1 e& uh 2 e& uh 3 e& uh 4 e& uh". Is that standardized?
i'd say so. it's spelled 1 e & a
So if I say that, everyone will understand that e.g. the "e" syllable is before the "&"? I've seen a couple questions and answers on here that seem to use this kind of notation.

yes, it's also like an address for when a note is. if you say a note is "on the and of 4" that means it's the last 8th note of the bar. if you say something is "on the a of 2" that would be the second 16th note in the second beat, in other words the 6th 16th note of the bar
Also, how do you count odd time signatures that way?
would be the same probably, unless it's like 6/8 or 9/8 or 12/8 etc, which by convention are usually based in groups of 3 8th notes.
Do they have standardized ways of saying them as well?
less so

Hello Bill. The universe is so humongous big. And it's basically empty. So nothing that we do really matters. And yet it does. Because we are a small spark of self-consciousness in what appears to be a never-ending expanse of lifelessness. There is all of this stuff here, but it's so far apart in all of this nothingness. It doesn't matter, because we are so small, and yet it's the only thing that matters because we the planets are all that really exist. Going around stars that give us heat and energy and life and brought us into this world and keep us safe in their gravity wells. This solar system is our playground and we're both spoiling and squandering it. So many beautiful worlds that we could get to know. The things we aren't doing could save us from our eventual demise, and the things that we are doing are speeding it up. We are trapped on this planet by our own ineptitude and our own inability to just be cool to one another and try to think ab out how  cool the universe is. That's why I like you. You make music that's chill and gets people thinking about how cool shit is. I want to help make more people think about the universe before it's too late because they've just been thinking about themselves. I feel lost and confused and don't know how to start. I tried some stuff but it just got me in trouble and I lost my job because apparently music isn't professional and shouldn't be shared over work email. A lot of other shit happened too. Now I'm broken and tired and just want to run away to the wilderness but it doesn't exist anymore, especially not in the polluted and soon-to-be-underwater concrete hellscape that is Florida. I'm lost and confused and finding hope in your music even though I hate what trying to follow in your footsteps has done to my life. I just wanna run away from the bad. I just wanna run towards the good. I just wanna run. And yet all I can seem to do is cry for the mistakes we as a living planet have ma de and t he things we have done to ourself. I love this universe. I hate this universe. It's fascinating and brilliant. It's horrible and cruel. It has so much potential and so much risk. I just want to help it. And yet I feel so incapable of doing so. Can we please just start to be a real planet with real goals and dreams and impressive accomplishments instead of a ball of fighting jerks that will destroy itself? I don't know what to do anymore.

we are getting there and have been getting there for a long time. we have made crazy progress. i did some world history research and found out we all used to be rocks for an extremely long time. then some how we discovered, 1 bit at a time, how to have more fun. and each discovery is faster and wilder than the previous

I absolutely love the new song. I'm very curious about the time signature when you sing "ba da dee da da dee do". How would that be notated? Did you change from 4/4 to 7/8? It sounds so fascinating. Please enlighten me!

Hmmm is there any particular reason why some people use Cb to refer to B or E# to refer to F? Coz I've seen this in a couple places (mainly Synthesia)

it's not some people, it's some situations. if you are in the key of Gb, there is the B note but if you call it B then you have Gb, Ab, Bb, B, Db, Eb. this gets real messy if you try to put it on the staff. to use a key signature on a staff you just flat everything you need and then play the scale, with all the letters laid out. so you can't have 2 B notes, you'd have to keep flatting and sharping it. the same would be true for E#, which would be the last note the key of F# major. if you called if F it would be a mess when you write on the staff, you'd have to keep sharping and unsharping the F

Why can't you have a strumming guitar?

i can, but recording a guitar would break a boundary that i have thus far never broken. it's not that i couldn't break it, but i have always been vastly able to accomplish everything i've needed without breaking that boundary. it's kind of like when you are writing essays for school and you are typing all of them. you are typing and typing and typing and typing and typing, and then you want some different fonts so you change the font and that's cool and good. and then you get to a part where you might actually need to write it on paper with an actual quill and ink. you may have a quill in the closet and you think it works and you think you know how to use it maybe .... but do you have paper? maybe/maybe not ... but they sell paper at the store and you think you could probably get the paper .... but what will really happen if you put the quill on to that paper? will there be any unexpected twists and challenges? also you have to get the image back into the computer somehow. ... and you might have a scanner but you are not sure if it works ... and then you will have to make sure it is integrated into your digital work in a way that feels right and makes sense. But you have never gotten around to think about any of this because you have learned to get absolutely everything done by using fonts in innovative ways. so as i said it's an entirely different door which i have avoided opening for a long time, and many people used to lecture me in the past about how i could never succeed without opening that door. but i never listened to them and i never opened the door, because i have always felt that i have had huge advantages otherwise. but i am now for the first time actually considering doing it. i only started considering this about 3 days ago but i'm really starting to think it might be a good idea. getting really sick of that fake banjo

Can you give me any tips on how to hear and distinguish a fully diminished chord from a half diminished chord?
yes
Do you instantly know what it is or do you have to actively concentrate to the 7th?

one thing to remember with 'diminished' chords is, the way they work is upside down. once you get that it starts to make more sense. so when you say the '7th', it actually doesn't really feel or sound like a 7th of anything. let me give you some examples... key of C. first chord C. second chord, just move the bass note up 1, and keep the other notes, so it's C#, E, G. that's C#dim. so it's like C but with the C note moved up. and the chord actually behaves almost just like A7. so a lot of songs may start C, C#dim, when actually it is a very close sister of C, A7. you'll notice this in a lot of songs, especially from the 1930s or 40s. On the subject of the "diminished 7" well that sounds pretty much the same. it's just a continuation of the diminished thing, it's all stacked 3rds, a very dizzy sound. and again to use the previous example, it would be like C7, then if you move the C note up and keep the rest the same that is just like C#dim7. and again, it's like a substitute for A7b9. wants to go to Dmin in both cases, and most often will. C, C#dim, Dmin. .... but the other one you asked about, half-dim, (or some people call it min7b5) again the 7th won't really feel like a 7th of anything, because diminished chords don't really sit on their feet, they hang from above, as i'm trying to explain, so actually generally what i would say is, a half-dim chord is gonna sound like a minor triad with a certain note in the bass. let's say, Fmin with D in the bass. that's what it sounds like. let's go to the key of Cmin, and let's say you have Fmin, G7, Cmin. if you take that chord sequence, and listen closely, and plug the headphones into your smartphone, you will notice secretly there might be a D bass note under that Fmin. that makes it Dmin7b5 (or D half-dim) instead. the names of these chords are kind of misleading and don't particularly feel like good names for them but that's just the names that are used. probably less so nowadays because this kind of literacy has fallen somewhat out of style .... but the example i just mentioned is generally the most common way you will hear those chords used. the main thing to remember here is that diminished chords mostly mostly mostly usually nearly always do NOT stand on their own and are not used on their own. so if you start to think too much about the chord individually it will not seem to make sense. yet it occurs very normally and commonly as part of a sequence. so the best thing you can do is just look at where it occurs in songs, and just become accustomed to those patterns. and then you will recognize the pattern. and when you hear that Dhalf-dim, G7, Cmin, you will instantly know it is either that OR Fmin, G7, Cmin. but you will have to plug in the headphones and listen close to see if that D bass note is there, to know for sure which it is. but you were asking about the difference between Ddim and Dhalf-dim, well i would say that those 2 aren't the ones you wanna tell the difference between, they're not really even that closely related. i'd say it's more about telling the difference between Dhalf-dim and Fmin. and the difference between Ddim and Bb7. and in both cases you would need to turn up the bass to hear the difference but there is not that much difference. the way you would tell the difference between Ddim and Dhalf-dim is just that they are used in different parts of the song. it's kind of like a wrench and a broom. you can usually tell which one is which because they are mostly not even used in the same context. but the biggest thing i can say, again, is just look at the songs and just find out what happens in songs
Also, why is it so difficult for me to distinguish a diminished triad from an augmented triad?
they have a similar dizzying effect because you are stacking 2 minor 3rds or 2 major thirds in a row, pushing it out of key

It really shouldn't be, they're way too different and yet I have a hard time doing it. 
I can tell the difference between these chords if I try really hard to isolate pitches but I want to be able to instantly hear and know what it is, just like I can instantly distinguish a major from a minor chord. Do you have any advice? Many thanks

i hope you are doing this from inside a song and not outside. because dim and aug chords in particular are very much out of context if they are used outside of a song. and with aug, it's almost like borderline it's almost unfair that that one even has a name. because when you get into that territory it's like you're doing a song and you just need to change one note a certain way and you do it. and there might not really be a name for the chord. usually you don't just go around playing augmented chords .... the fact that it has a name make it seem like more of a solid/usable thing than it really is. in other words, the places it is used almost always seems like a sort of exception of some kind. there are many other patterns of notes that are sort of built out of all wholetones, etc, which are a complete mess to try to name. and i feel that a straight up augmented triad is in that family and is kind of unfair that that one gets such an easy name. and i've seen a lot of people get distracted early on trying to learn what it means and what its importance is, just because it gets brought up early in classes along with minor and major chords. but really it's something that should be discovered through songs, as needed. along with all the other things which may not have names

someone also said the bass was weak, so i tried to run the bass a little louder. someone also said the bass was still weak after i did that.

Hello, do you have any advice for learning different keys for piano (A, Bb, etc...) I am pretty much self taught, but i struggle with learning keys.

you'll have to take some songs you know already and then play them in the next key. if it's in C, and you know it in C, try learning it in F. if you are having trouble figuring out what key the song you know is in, ..... try very simple songs ? like the alphabet song for example, if you play that in C the first 2 notes are C. that would be in the key of C. that doesn't mean every song starts on the note of the key it's in, but some songs do .... i think you should start by learning a lot of simple songs in the key of C. i think you will get used to it ... it's kind of like learning which wall of a room is the floor ... there's no rule but you can usually get a feel for it. then once you know a bunch of songs in C then start learning all those songs in F. it should look exactly the same except you will have to swap in 1 black note to make it sound right. get used to that and then you can go to the next key (Bb) in which you will have to swap in 1 more black note. or, go backwards, back to C, then go the other way to the next key (G), in which case you will have to swap in a a different black note the other way. if you go through the keys this way (C,  F, Bb, Eb) it will be only 1 slight twist each time and you should learn it fine. or going the other direction it's C, G, D, A, etc

Hi Bill.

So I've got a pretty good relative pitch. Once I know the note of one pitch, I can pretty much tell the rest because I have a reference. But I want to tell a pitch without a reference.

Can you teach me how to do that?
yes
I know perfect pitch is not the most important thing in the world but I just want to know if it's possible to learn.
you can't get really hard wired for absolute pitch unless you do it before you are about 6 years old
I want to identify notes without reference.

the good news is, it's not that hard to do, you just won't be as fast as those who are super hard wired AP. who knows, you may even catch some in a lie ...... but anyway, start by memorizing the key of every song you know, and every common beep and tone in your society. (microwaves, car horns, your electronic devices, etc. just get to know them all. you probably won't forget). based on your early childhood experience, you may find that you have at least one note absolutized in your memory. and you can learn to work with that quite easily, although 12 times slower than someone who had all 12 absolutized from childhood. i've actually never met anyone who has that, and i've never heard of anyone having that while also being really good and comfortable with everything musical / relativity has to offer. i trust that it's possible but haven't seen it yet. which is somewhat re-assuring to those of us who forgot to learn in any key other than C until age ........ 7
